qas.question: What was bundled for free with the Windows OS?
Internet Explorer was partially funded in what two ways?

answers.text: sales of Windows to computer manufacturers and direct to users

qas.question: What other OS could use Internet Explorer?
What program was bundled free with Java?

plausible_answers.text: the sales of Windows to computer manufacturers and direct to users

qas.question: What helped to partly fund Java?
For what OS was Java formerly available for?

plausible_answers.text: was part of Microsoft's overall strategy to fight threats to its quasi-monopoly platform dominance

qas.question: Why was Java available for the Mac?
In what other way did Java contribute to Windows and Microsoft application sales?

context: <a0_0><b3_0>Internet Explorer<b3_0/><a0_0/>, on the other hand, was bundled free with the Windows operating system (and was also downloadable free), and therefore it was funded partly by <b4_0>the <a1_0>sales of Windows to computer manufacturers and direct to users<b4_0/><a1_0/>. Internet Explorer also used to be available for <b5_0>the <a2_0>Mac<b5_0/><a2_0/>. It is likely that releasing IE for the Mac <b6_0>was part of Microsoft's overall strategy to fight threats to its quasi-monopoly platform dominance<b6_0/> - threats such as web standards and Java - by making some web developers, or at least their managers, assume that there was "no need" to develop for anything other than Internet Explorer. In this respect, IE may have contributed to Windows and Microsoft applications sales in another way, <b7_0>through "lock-in" to Microsoft's browser<b7_0/>.
